basics.name: Chunde Huang
basics.label: Software Engineer & physicist
basics.summary: I am a seasoned software engineer with over ten years of experience in software development (C++/C#/Python). In 2013, I transitioned from industry to academia to pursue a Ph.D. in physics, expanding my expertise to include quantum computing, cold atom experiment, and the quantum simulation of superfluidity. My diverse background in computer science and physics positions me to excel in interdisciplinary research. I am eager to leverage my extensive knowledge to tackle exciting and challenging projects that will change the future well beings of humankind, such as quantum computing, artificial intelligence, robotics and biological engineering etc.

work.name: KLA-Tencor
work.summary: Teaching at Palmer Physical Laboratory (now 302 Frist Campus Center). While not a professor at Princeton, I associated with the physics professors and continued to give lectures on campus.Senior C++ Software Engineer at KLA, focused on designing and developing complex system control software for advanced machines valued in the tens to hundreds of millions. This role demands expertise across multiple disciplines, including computer science, electrical and mechanical engineering, optics, laser technology, and vacuum systems.

work.name: CGG
work.summary: Spent one year at CGG, focusing on imaging analysis and extensive data preprocessing. Responsibilities included data denoising, domain migration, and modeling to generate detailed subsurface structures, supporting clients in subsurface exploration and risk reduction.

awards.title: Second Prize in the National Academic Contest of Challenge Cup for 2010 Shanghai World Exposition
awards.awarder: Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China
awards.summary: I developed a prize-winning facial recognition system in Beijing, built primarily in C++ and C# with optimized Intel assembly code to enhance graphic processing and boost algorithmic performance. The system features a sleek, user-friendly interface and achieves real-time processing capabilities.

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
